subject: Data
title: Google's PageRank: Organizing the Web's Data
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Google's PageRank: Organizing the Web's Data.

hook.text: By 1998, the web had millions of pages. Searching for anything returned a mess of irrelevant results.

buildup.text: Two Stanford students realized that links between pages were signals â€” like academic citations.

discovery.text: PageRank ranked pages by how many other pages linked to them. Popular pages floated to the top.

twist.text: Their professors told them search was a solved problem. Larry Page and Sergey Brin disagreed.

climax.text: Google became the gateway to the world's data, handling 8.5 billion searches every single day.

punchline.text: They organized the internet with a homework project.

quiz.question: What principle does Google's PageRank use to rank web pages?
options: Number and quality of links pointing to a page
